nodes.bodyText:
I think essentially the PR wants to distinguish the data presentation from the data itself in the sortable table. Therefore, you may not want the rows to by of type any[]. Instead, we can define a new interface
export interface TableRow {
    value: any, // value used for sorting with sortBy provided in ColumnData
    displayableValue?: any; // displayable value 
    componentInput?: Record<string, any>; // @Input values for customized component if specified in ColumnData
}

By doing this, the data presentation (use dynamic component or just plain-string displayable value) is separated from the data (value) itself.
I think the current type definition any[][] | CustomTableCellData[][] is a bit confusing as it will enforce nothing since we have any.

Yeah I agree. It was quite awkward writing any[][] | CustomTableCellData[][].
Another question I have is whether I should provide the component every time in the individual cell data, or to specify it once in the column itself.
export interface TableRow {
    value: any, // value used for sorting with sortBy provided in ColumnData
    displayableValue?: any; // displayable value 
    component: Type<any>; // <-- Do I put this here?
    componentInput?: Record<string, any>; // @Input values for customized component if specified in ColumnData
}

Feels like it would introduce a stronger relationship between the component and the componentInput, which would make more sense?
Let's keep it simple. Personally I do not foresee any possibility that we will use different components for different cells that belong to the same column.

Actually I wasn't worrying about that.
I felt that the relationship between the column and the row might not be clear enough to the caller. As you can see, I had to put a lot of comments to highlight to the user that the row and the column must be aligned, and the user must remember which cells uses which component from which column. Putting them in the same object structure would get rid of all these ambiguity
Sure. We can also got for this solution.

nodes.bodyText: Is defining the module really necessary?

Not really necessary, but I think it helps make the code more organized. Especially since I added a new ContributionRatingsListComponent. Now's there's 3 components used by the contribution statistics. Grouping them together would be nice.
Tooltips weren't working previous. Added a fix in here

nodes.bodyText:
One annoying thing is that the caller must remember to register their dynamic component here. Maybe should document this somewhere?
From the docs here, it seems like this step can be skipped if we upgrade to Angular 9, but since we are at Angular 8, we are using this doc instead, which requires the registration of these components.
Will open issue to track this as a reminder if we ever upgrade to Angular 9.

nodes.bodyText: We should describe the function of the module other than where the module is used.

Actually I put it under sortable-table.component.ts file.
/**
 * Displays a sortable table, sorting by clicking on the header
 * Optional sortBy option provided for each column
 * Columns and rows provided must be aligned
 * Remember to register new dynamic components using the withComponents method under sortable-table-module
 */

Should I move it or copy it over to the module file?

The module itself does not contains any sortable table components so the documentation should not mention it (e.g., consider the case where the module is used in places other than sortable table. It is still suitable to write Module for displaying data in a sortable table?).

Hmm sorry I'm not too clear about the distinction between Angular components and modules. So what kind of information should I include here? Because I don't see a use case for importing this module without using the sortable table component.

Now's there's 3 components used by the contribution statistics. Grouping them together would be nice.

Quote your words :P Modules help you organize your component better (there are other benefits like lazy-load which you can see more on the Angular documentation).
Let's put it in this way. When you group similar things together and you want to describe the group. Do you usually describe what the group is or where the group is used?

Let's put it in this way. When you group similar things together and you want to describe the group. Do you usually describe what the group is or where the group is used?

Would describe what the group is. But it does gets a bit weird here though, seeing that the module only contains 1 component.
So i'll just say something like this?
/**
 * Sortable table module.
 */
Ohhh. I think we are talking about two things. The comment I given is for the file: contribution-question-statistics.module.ts not sortable-table.module.ts.
Ohhh i must have read wrongly. Just changed it.
